messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: 𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖰𝖨𝖯=𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤

Paper Abstract: Abstract Complexity theory traditionally studies the hardness of solving classical computational problems. In the quantum setting, it is also natural to consider a different notion of complexity, namely the complexity of physically preparing a certain quantum state. We study the relation between two such state complexity classes: 𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤\mathsf{statePSPACE}, which contains states that can be generated by space-uniform polynomial-space quantum circuits, and 𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖰𝖨𝖯𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖰𝖨𝖯\mathsf{stateQIP}, which contains states that a polynomial-time quantum verifier can generate by interacting with an all-powerful untrusted quantum prover. The latter class was recently introduced by Rosenthal and Yuen (ITCS 2022), who proved that 𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤⊆𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖰𝖨𝖯𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖰𝖨𝖯\mathsf{statePSPACE}\subseteq\mathsf{stateQIP}. Our main result is the reverse inclusion, 𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖰𝖨𝖯⊆𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖰𝖨𝖯𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤\mathsf{stateQIP}\subseteq\mathsf{statePSPACE}, thereby establishing equality of the two classes and providing a natural state-complexity analogue to the celebrated 𝖰𝖨𝖯=𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤𝖰𝖨𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤\mathsf{QIP}=\mathsf{PSPACE} theorem of Jain, et al. (J. ACM 2011). To prove this, we develop a polynomial-space quantum algorithm for solving a large class of exponentially large “𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤\mathsf{PSPACE}-computable” semidefinite programs (SDPs), which also prepares an optimiser encoded in a quantum state. Our SDP solver relies on recent block-encoding techniques from quantum algorithms, demonstrating that these techniques are also useful for complexity theory. Using similar techniques, we also show that optimal prover strategies for general quantum interactive protocols can be implemented in quantum polynomial space. We prove this by studying an algorithmic version of Uhlmann’s theorem and establishing an upper bound on the complexity of implementing Uhlmann transformations.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The complexity of quantum states and transformations: from quantum money to black holes",
        "The mother of all protocols: Restructuring quantum information’s family tree",
        "Fast algorithms for approximate semidefinite programming using the multiplicative weights update method",
        "Quantum versus classical proofs and advice",
        "A combinatorial, primal-dual approach to semidefinite programs",
        "Exponential improvement in precision for simulating sparse hamiltonians",
        "Simulating hamiltonian dynamics with a truncated taylor series",
        "Parallel computation for well-endowed rings and space-bounded probabilistic machines",
        "Matrix analysis, volume 169",
        "Quantum SDP solvers: Large speed-ups, optimality, and applications to quantum learning",
        "A fast parallel algorithm for determining all roots of a polynomial with real roots",
        "On relating time and space to size and depth",
        "Quantum speed-ups for solving semidefinite programs",
        "Fast parallel matrix and GCD computations",
        "Fast parallel matrix inversion algorithms",
        "Quantum Merlin-Arthur proof systems for synthesizing quantum states",
        "Quantum Merlin-Arthur with exponentially small gap",
        "Eliminating intermediate measurements in space-bounded quantum computation",
        "Quantum singular value transformation & its algorithmic applications",
        "Distributed Merlin-Arthur Synthesis of Quantum States and Its Applications",
        "Creating superpositions that correspond to efficiently integrable probability distributions",
        "Eliminating intermediate measurements using pseudorandom generators",
        "Fixed-point quantum search",
        "Quantum singular value transformation and beyond: exponential improvements for quantum matrix arithmetics",
        "Parallel approximation of min-max problems with applications to classical and quantum zero-sum games",
        "Quantum computation vs. firewalls",
        "Quantum state merging and negative information",
        "Black holes as mirrors: quantum information in random subsystems",
        "Quantum search-to-decision reductions and the state synthesis problem",
        "𝖰𝖨𝖯=𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤𝖰𝖨𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤\\mathsf{QIP}=\\mathsf{PSPACE}",
        "Two-message quantum interactive proofs are in PSPACE",
        "Efficient algorithms using the multiplicative weights update method",
        "Efficient approximation algorithms for semidefinite programs arising from max cut and coloring",
        "Parallelization, amplification, and exponential time simulation of quantum interactive proof systems",
        "Is quantum bit commitment really possible?",
        "Hamiltonian simulation by uniform spectral amplification",
        "Hamiltonian simulation by qubitization",
        "Algebraic methods for interactive proof systems",
        "Grand unification of quantum algorithms",
        "Quantum Computation and Quantum Information: 10th Anniversary Edition",
        "Specified precision polynomial root isolation is in nc",
        "On the maximum errors of polynomial approximations defined by interpolation and by least squares criteria",
        "Quantum information theory",
        "Interactive proofs for synthesizing quantum states and unitaries",
        "Approximating linear programming is log-space complete for P",
        "𝖨𝖯=𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤𝖨𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤\\mathsf{IP}=\\mathsf{PSPACE}",
        "Faster algorithms via approximation theory",
        "The “transition probability” in the state space of a ∗*-algebra",
        "Quantum SDP-solvers: Better upper and lower bounds",
        "Quantum proofs",
        "On the complexity of simulating space-bounded quantum computations",
        "Equilibrium value method for the proof of 𝖰𝖨𝖯=𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤𝖰𝖨𝖯𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤\\mathsf{QIP}=\\mathsf{PSPACE}",
        "Fixed-point quantum search with an optimal number of queries"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in 𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖰𝖨𝖯=𝗌𝗍𝖺𝗍𝖾𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
